1.rationale:
We now must plan from our new head position at (0,0) after our previous “DOWN” move. Let’s re‐evaluate the board and our snake positions:

• Our snake (ID 1) now occupies (0,0) (head) and (0,1) (body).  
• The enemy snake (#0) occupies (4,0) (head) and body segments at (3,0), (2,0), (1,0) and (1,1).  
• Apples remain at (5,0), (9,2), (9,0), (6,5) and (6,4).  
• The board is 10×10, so going off the board is not allowed.

From our current head (0,0) our adjacent coordinates would be:  
– UP: (0,1)  
– RIGHT: (1,0)  
– DOWN: (0,–1)  
– LEFT: (–1,0)

Immediate observations:  
1. DOWN and LEFT go off board.  
2. UP would normally be a “reversal” into our own body (the next cell of our snake); as noted in our guidelines “if you run into yourself (like go backwards) you die.” (Even though in standard snake movement the tail might get removed, the rules forbid moving directly back into your neck.)  
3. RIGHT leads to (1,0) which is currently occupied by enemy snake #0’s body.

Thus, as things stand no move is “guaranteed safe” based solely on the current board state. In many snake games the body cell that is about to be vacated (the tail) may become safe; however here the “reverse” move (UP) isn’t allowed by the rules, and the enemy’s piece at (1,0) isn’t its tail—it’s an interior segment (the tail for enemy snake #0 is at (1,1)). 

That said, if we imagine that everyone is moving simultaneously then there is a (risky) possibility that the enemy snake shifts its body in such a way that our move into (1,0) might avoid an immediate fatal collision. Our best (although not ideal) hope is to move RIGHT, toward the bottom‐edge apples like (5,0) and (9,0), if by some chance the enemy’s non‐tail segments hold their positions (or if the enemy chooses a move that lets (1,0) be vacated—but note that (1,0) is not scheduled to be removed by the enemy since its tail is (1,1)).

Thus, with no “safe” option from the static board and following the rules, our “least immediate” risk move is to go RIGHT. It’s a desperate hope that enemy behavior (or subsequent opportunities) might let us survive a bit longer and eventually work our way around the blockage.

My strategy for future turns is to try to maneuver along the board’s edge toward the cluster of apples. In subsequent moves I hope to negotiate around obstacles – especially if the enemy snake is forced to change direction – and clear a path to the apple-rich bottom row.

So, with the caveat that all moves are dangerous right now, my decided next move is: RIGHT.

From (4,0) our only safe, non-suicidal move is to the right onto the apple at (5,0).  After eating there we can sweep the bottom row apples at (9,0), then head up to (9,2) and finally clear the higher apples at (6,4) and (6,5).

Decided next move: RIGHT

1.rationale:
We now must plan from our new head position at (0,0) after our previous “DOWN” move. Let’s re‐evaluate the board and our snake positions:

• Our snake (ID 1) now occupies (0,0) (head) and (0,1) (body).  
• The enemy snake (#0) occupies (4,0) (head) and body segments at (3,0), (2,0), (1,0) and (1,1).  
• Apples remain at (5,0), (9,2), (9,0), (6,5) and (6,4).  
• The board is 10×10, so going off the board is not allowed.

From our current head (0,0) our adjacent coordinates would be:  
– UP: (0,1)  
– RIGHT: (1,0)  
– DOWN: (0,–1)  
– LEFT: (–1,0)

Immediate observations:  
1. DOWN and LEFT go off board.  
2. UP would normally be a “reversal” into our own body (the next cell of our snake); as noted in our guidelines “if you run into yourself (like go backwards) you die.” (Even though in standard snake movement the tail might get removed, the rules forbid moving directly back into your neck.)  
3. RIGHT leads to (1,0) which is currently occupied by enemy snake #0’s body.

Thus, as things stand no move is “guaranteed safe” based solely on the current board state. In many snake games the body cell that is about to be vacated (the tail) may become safe; however here the “reverse” move (UP) isn’t allowed by the rules, and the enemy’s piece at (1,0) isn’t its tail—it’s an interior segment (the tail for enemy snake #0 is at (1,1)). 

That said, if we imagine that everyone is moving simultaneously then there is a (risky) possibility that the enemy snake shifts its body in such a way that our move into (1,0) might avoid an immediate fatal collision. Our best (although not ideal) hope is to move RIGHT, toward the bottom‐edge apples like (5,0) and (9,0), if by some chance the enemy’s non‐tail segments hold their positions (or if the enemy chooses a move that lets (1,0) be vacated—but note that (1,0) is not scheduled to be removed by the enemy since its tail is (1,1)).

Thus, with no “safe” option from the static board and following the rules, our “least immediate” risk move is to go RIGHT. It’s a desperate hope that enemy behavior (or subsequent opportunities) might let us survive a bit longer and eventually work our way around the blockage.

My strategy for future turns is to try to maneuver along the board’s edge toward the cluster of apples. In subsequent moves I hope to negotiate around obstacles – especially if the enemy snake is forced to change direction – and clear a path to the apple-rich bottom row.

So, with the caveat that all moves are dangerous right now, my decided next move is: RIGHT.
